ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course improved by writing skills and helped me to see the larger picture of these works in a political context. It was a great introduction to college seminars and I learned a lot from my classmates and my instructor. Professor Thompson leads a very student-focused seminar that allows opportunities to explore new ideas and question each other around key passages.

This course made me a better writer, reader, and thinker. I am eternally grateful to Prof. Thompson for her insights, mentorship, and skilled classroom leadership. Prof. Thompson runs the most organized, engaging, and interesting seminar I have ever participated in. Her notes for each text discussed were longer than the text itself! With her guidance, DS H&P gave me an invaluable understanding of the development of historical and political thought from the Hebrew Bible to Aquinas. I now have an in-depth understanding of the intersection of religion, politics, history, and storytelling.
Writing skills and discussion with peers
This course substantially improved my ability not only to write about my ideas but also to formulate and discuss them in a highly sophisticated way.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was all strengths honestly. A lot of people complain about the workload for DS, and doing the reading is very important in this section because pretty much everything is covered in class, but I think the workload (while intense) is certainly manageable, and I feel like I gained something from every reading because we talked about it all.

The strengths are so numerous they would be impossible to list here. See my answer to Question 1 for more detail. The only (minor) weakness which comes to mind is the length of the readings. It was a struggle every class to discuss each section, and at times, some of the sections assigned (especially from "City of God") seemed superfluous.
I liked the small discussion format of this course, but the pace is very fast, at times (for me) unmanageably so.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course. DS is incredible and this section in particular was my absolute favorite. It's a great way to adjust to college and develop crucial skills with a great group of people and instructors.

I would highly recommend this course to other students. Anyone who seeks a greater understanding of our world in all of its political and historical complexity needs to take this course. You will leave Prof. Thompson's class with a deep understanding of what it means to be a "political animal" and a citizen.

If you can, take H&Por really any classwith Prof. Thompson. She is a gem. The reading load in DS is heavy, of course, but Prof. Thompson does a phenomenal job of picking out important sections and guiding the class towards them without overly controlling the discussion. Of my three fall DS seminars, I would say that this was the best as far as student participation, largely due to Prof. Thompson's ability to engage everyone and lead a marvelous discussion.
You have to be ready to do a lot of readying and work, but if you are interested in history its a really cool form of learning.
